hints.content: Start by understanding how to remove the smallest and largest 5% of the elements from the array. You will need to calculate how many elements that corresponds to based on the length of the array.
Remember that the array length is guaranteed to be a multiple of 20. This means that you can calculate 5% easily as it will always be a whole number.
To find the smallest and largest elements, you might want to sort the array first. Sorting will help you easily access the elements you need to remove.
After sorting, the smallest 5% of elements will be the first few elements in the sorted array, while the largest 5% will be the last few elements.
Once you have identified the elements to remove, create a new array that contains only the elements that are not in the smallest or largest 5%.
Make sure to handle the case where the array has exactly 20 elements, as removing 5% means removing 1 element from both ends.
After filtering the array, you need to calculate the mean of the remaining elements. The mean is calculated as the sum of the elements divided by the count of those elements.
Be careful with floating-point arithmetic when calculating the mean. Ensure that your final result is formatted correctly to meet the precision requirements.
Consider edge cases where all the elements are the same, or where the array contains the minimum and maximum possible values. These cases might affect the mean calculation.
Finally, implement the logic to return the mean of the remaining integers. Make sure to format your output to 5 decimal places, as specified in the problem statement.

questionNotes: Constraints: 20 <= arr.length <= 1000, arr.length is a multiple of 20.
You need to remove the smallest and largest 5% of elements.
Ensure the output mean is within 10^-5 of the actual answer.
Consider edge cases with identical elements or extreme values.
